Javascript is moving in the right direction with the new ES6+ versions. But the JS ecosystem is still too young. Using NPM gives me the impression of going back 15 years ago when Maven didn't exist. There was then no clear building conventions between different Java projects and you had to write you whole building process using scripts and makefiles. This lack of conventions and maturity sweats from the whole JS ecosystem. For instance relative imports in a NodeJS project are a really dumb idea. In general, the overwelming towards JS these 5 last years are a bit difficult to understand. JS starts to be used in places it was never inteded to (NodeJS) where good and mature languages like Python can do a considerably better work. hopefully in 7-10 years, the language will stabilize and go with clear and strong convention for project, stop creating a new x.JS tool that reinvent the wheel and keep things simple and stupid.

I'm a backend developer turned frontend (mostly creative) developer. A large part of my time is spent writing GLSL, handling typed arrays and optimizing run time execution.

I'm surprised there are no question on WebAudio, WebGL, TypedArray, WebWorker (not ServiceWorker), WebVR, SVG, Gamepad API, WebAssembly, FP, OOP, etc. in this survey. Those technologies and paradigms are much more important in my eyes than most of what this survey is focusing on, which for the most part is mere tooling.

The focus on tooling is what is harming the JavaScript community. Beginners are way too often lured (through tutorials and tech articles reading as ads and PR pieces) or forced (by company policies) into dependency-heavy boilerplates which are abstracting away what they should be learning, instead of learning the current API of the framework/build-tool du jour. All this transient knowledge becomes obsolete as soon as a new tool come along with enough PR effort behind it to win over the community.

I'm still excited about the future of JavaScript and by extension the future of the web in general, not about the next big lib/framework/tool.

- Will my coworker know how to extend my code? (what does he/she usually use?)
- Will it be easy to find answers? (size of the community?/backed by billion dollar corp.?)
- How far can I get with an "off the shelf"-ish solution (create-react-app, `rails new`, etc.)

'd just like to interject for moment. What you're refering to as Linux, is in fact, GNU/Linux, or as I've recently taken to calling it, GNU plus Linux. Linux is not an operating system unto itself, but rather another free component of a fully functioning GNU system made useful by the GNU corelibs, shell utilities and vital system components comprising a full OS as defined by POSIX.

Many computer users run a modified version of the GNU system every day, without realizing it. Through a peculiar turn of events, the version of GNU which is widely used today is often called Linux, and many of its users are not aware that it is basically the GNU system, developed by the GNU Project.

There really is a Linux, and these people are using it, but it is just a part of the system they use. Linux is the kernel: the program in the system that allocates the machine's resources to the other programs that you run. The kernel is an essential part of an operating system, but useless by itself; it can only function in the context of a complete operating system. Linux is normally used in combination with the GNU operating system: the whole system is basically GNU with Linux added, or GNU/Linux. All the so-called Linux distributions are really distributions of GNU/Linux!

WebAssembly. We need to bridge the gap between web and native. Right now, we have things like GRPC, which is basically TCP on top of HTTP... on top of TCP. We have react, which is basically the DOM on top of Javascript, on top of the DOM. We have hacks that help workaround poorly maintained software, and those hacks become commonplace, and when those hacks fail to get the job done, more hacks are built on top of the previous hacks - rinse and repeat. I'm a grumpy 20-something in the camp of "build something any idiot can use, and any idiot /will/ use it". The web is too easy and we're building a mountain of cruddy code because of it. There is no accountability and shooting yourself in the foot is common practice. Performance and profiling are dead, and the rift between native and web is too vast.
